properties.sfomuseum:description: Interview conducted by Mauree Jane Perry on March 22, 1999.This interview describes Captain Hillier’s experiences as fifth officer, fourth officer, flight engineer, navigator, co-pilot, and pilot with Pan American World Airways from 1942 to 1980; civilian flight training at Meisinger Flying Service; his work as a flight instructor at Plains Airways in Fort Morgan, Colorado; his work for the Civil Aeronautics Administration; his military training; his ground training with Pan American in Walnut Creek, California; discusses flights originating at Treasure Island; culture of Pan American workers in the San Francisco Bay Area between 1942 and 1945; aircraft he flew: Martin M-130 China Clipper, Boeing 314, 377 Stratocruiser, 707, and 747, Douglas DC-3 and DC-4, Grumman Goose; routes he flew: Pacific Division from San Francisco to Hawaii, Palmyra, Canton Island, Wallace, Fiji, Funafuti, Noumea, Brisbane, Auckland, Korea, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore, Vietnam, and Guam, in the Latin American Division from Miami to Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, Costa Rica, Panama, Venezuela, Guiana, Brazil (Belem), Buenos Aires, Cat Cay, and Andros Island, around-the-world routes; describes the process of celestial navigation; experiences while flying during wartime and Pan American’s cooperation with the United States military; changes as aircraft technology advanced; work disruptions he experienced as a result; Air Line Pilot’s Association; encounters with Juan Trippe, Charles Lindbergh, and the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.
